Task-Load-Aware Game-Theoretic Framework for Wireless Federated Learning

Jiawei Liu, Guopeng Zhang, Kezhi Wang, and Kun Yang Jiawei Liu and Guopeng Zhang are with the School of Computer Science and Technology, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou 221116, China (e-mail: jwliu@cumt.edu.cn; gpzhang@cumt.edu.cn).Kezhi Wang is with the Department of Computer and Information Science, Northumbria University, Newcastle NE1 8ST, U.K. (e-mail: kezhi.wang@northumbria.ac.uk).Kun Yang is with the School of Computer Science and Electronic Engineering, University of Essex, Colchester CO4 3SQ, U.K. (e-mail: kunyang@essex.ac.uk).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) can protect data privacy but has difficulties in motivating user equipment (UE) to engage in task training. This paper proposes a Bertrand-game based framework to address the incentive problem, where a model owner (MO) issues an FL task and the employed UEs help train the model by using their local data. Specially, we consider the impact of time-varying task load and channel quality on UEâ€™s motivation to engage in the FL task. We adopt the finite-state discrete-time Markov chain (FSDT-MC) to predict these parameters during the FL task. Depending on the performance metrics set by the MO and the estimated energy cost of the FL task, each UE seeks to maximize its profit. We obtain the Nash equilibrium (NE) of the game in closed form, and develop a distributed iterative algorithm to find it. Finally, simulation result verifies the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

Index Terms:
Machine learning, federated learning, resource allocation, Bertrand game, Nash equilibrium.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [1] is a distributed machine learning (ML) framework that allows multiple clients to collaboratively train an ML model without exposing their raw data. In FL framework, a model owner (MO) first sends a global model to edge or mobile clients. Then the clients can train the model with their local data and transmit the updated model parameters to the MO for a new aggregated model. This process iterates until the required accuracy is achieved.

Although FL protects data privacy, it causes additional energy cost of clients for model training and parameter transmission, thus limiting their motivation to engage in FL [2]. To address this issue, a Stackelberg game is proposed in [3] to encourage clients to reduce the completion time of FL tasks. In [4], a reinforcement learning-based incentive mechanism is designed to find the optimal pricing and training strategies for the clients. In [5], a Stackelberg game is proposed to motivate the MO and clients to build a high-quality FL model. However, several strong assumptions were made in the above works, e.g., the clients have invariant task loads and channel quality during an FL task. These assumptions apply only to situations where the clients are computationally powerful edge servers connected with the wired networks. When the clients are mobile UEs, the energy and computation power are normally limited, thus the influence of time-varying task load and channel quality on their motivation to engage in FL may be considered.

Against the above background, this paper proposes a Bertrand-game[6] based framework to motivate UEs to engage in FL [7] [8], which considers the changes of task load and channel quality of UEs during an FL task. Firstly, given the performance metrics set by the MO, we show that the energy cost of a UE depends not only on the FL-task load but also on its existing-task load. We characterize the dynamic of userâ€™s future task load as an FSDT-MC [9]. Then, the energy cost of a UE caused by multiple rounds of local training can be predicted. Furthermore, we employ another FSDT-MC to describe the channel fading between a UE and the MO, as it has been widely used to simulate Rayleigh fading channels [10]. Then, the energy cost of the UE caused by multiple rounds of parameter transmission can also be estimated. Depending on the predicted overall energy cost for model training and parameter transmission, the UEs can charge the MO independently for the resource usage. At the NE of the game, the MO achieves a set of specified performance metrics with the minimum total payment, while each UE seeks the best price to maximize its own profit. The contribution of this paper is as follows:

1) By integrating the FSDT-MC based task load and channel quality prediction method, a Bertrand game is proposed to help motivate UEs to engage in FL based on the estimated overall energy cost.

2) The NE of the game is addressed in closed form, and an effective iterative algorithm is designed to obtain the NE in a distributed manner.

II-A Energy cost for model training

We use fk,texsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} to represent the CPU frequency of UE kğ‘˜k to process the EX-task, and assume that fk,texsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} remains constant during the local training session tğ‘¡t (1â‰¤tâ‰¤Ig1ğ‘¡superscriptğ¼g1\leq t\leq I^{\text{g}}) whose duration is Ttrnsuperscriptğ‘‡trnT^{\text{trn}}. To admit the FL-task, UE kğ‘˜k requires an additional Ck=ckâ€‹|ğ’Ÿk|â€‹Iksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜C_{k}=c_{k}|\mathcal{D}_{k}|I_{k} CPU cycles during each session tğ‘¡t, where cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} is the number of CPU cycles required for training per data sample dk,isubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğ‘–d_{k,i}. Therefore, UE kğ‘˜k should raise the CPU frequency by fk=Ck/Ttrnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‡trnf_{k}=C_{k}/T^{\text{trn}} Hz in each session to complete the newly carried FL-task. According to [11], the additional energy cost of UE kğ‘˜k during session tğ‘¡t is given as

where Î½ksubscriptğœˆğ‘˜\nu_{k} is the effective switched capacitance of the CPU. Let fmaxsuperscriptğ‘“maxf^{\text{max}} denote the maximum CPU frequency of the UEs. The following constraint should be satisfied.

From eq. (4), we know that Ek,tFsuperscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡FE_{k,t}^{\text{F}} depends not only on the FL-task load fksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜f_{k} but also on the EX-task load fkexsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜exf_{k}^{\text{ex}}, which causes the UEs to produce the same amount of CPU cycles, i.e., Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} but consume different amount of energy Ek,tFsuperscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡FE_{k,t}^{\text{F}}. It will affect the pricing strategy of the UEs in the game. It is noted that the fluctuation of the task load in the UE over a short period (e.g., a few tens of seconds) has some kind of randomness, but the task loads in the adjacent time periods may have a strong correlation [12]. Next, we propose an FSDT-MC based method [9] to predict the dynamic of fk,texsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} during the FL period. Therefore, each UE can estimate its energy cost for model training and set the price for the resource usage.

  1. 1.

    From ref. [12], we know that the workload fluctuation of a machine over a longer period (e.g., a few minutes) has a strong periodicity, while the workload fluctuation over a shorter period (e.g., a few tens of seconds) has a certain randomness, but the workloads in the adjacent time periods have a strong correlation.

  2. 2.

    In this paper, the time spent for a single round of local training is Ttrn=2superscriptğ‘‡trn2T^{\text{trn}}=2s, the time spent for a single round of parameter transmission is Tcom=0.2superscriptğ‘‡com0.2T^{\text{com}}=0.2s, and the total number of local training sessions is Ig=10superscriptğ¼g10I^{\text{g}}=10. Therefore, the total time required to complete a federated learning (FL) task is T=Igâ€‹(Ttrn+Tcom)=22ğ‘‡superscriptğ¼gsuperscriptğ‘‡trnsuperscriptğ‘‡com22T=I^{\text{g}}(T^{\text{trn}}+T^{\text{com}})=22s.

  3. 3.

    In the proposed game, the UEs must determine the price of the consumed resource during a FL task. In order to capture the short-term dynamic of usersâ€™ workload during the task, we set the observation interval and update period of QkFsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} to T=22ğ‘‡22T=22s (as stated in the response to your last question), and QkFsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘˜FQ_{k}^{\text{F}} can be timely updated by the workload changes collected at runtime.

II-B Energy cost for parameter transmission

After each round of local training, the MO assigns UE kğ‘˜k a time period Tcomsuperscriptğ‘‡comT^{\text{com}} and an orthogonal channel of Wğ‘ŠW Hz to upload the updated model parameter wksubscriptwğ‘˜\textbf{w}_{k}. Let Lğ¿L denote the size of wksubscriptwğ‘˜\textbf{w}_{k}, pk,tsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¡p_{k,t} the transmit power of UE kğ‘˜k, and gk,tsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜ğ‘¡g_{k,t} the channel gain from UE kğ‘˜k to the MO during the tthsuperscriptğ‘¡tht^{\text{th}} parameter transmission. Then, the achievable data rate of UE kğ‘˜k under a given bit error rate (BER) level can be approximated as

where Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is noise power and Î”=1.5âˆ’lnâ¡(5â€‹BER)Î”1.55BER\Delta=\frac{1.5}{-\ln(5\text{BER})} is a constant related to BER. Since rk,tâ€‹Tcomâ‰¥Lsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‡comğ¿r_{k,t}T^{\text{com}}\geq L should be satisfied, the minimum transmit power of UE kğ‘˜k is derived as

III Game Formulation

To motivate the UEs to engage in FL, an effective way is to enable the UEs to profit from the energy consumption of model training and data uploading. Game theory is a powerful tool to analyze the optimal or equilibrium strategies of the UEs in such a competitive situation. In general, strategic games can be divided into the following two categories [6]: (1) the production-based games, such as Cournot and Stackelberg games, which take the supply quantity of a commodity as a strategy to maximize the playersâ€™ profits, and (2) the price-based games, such as Bertrand games, which take the price of a commodity as a strategy to maximize the playersâ€™ profits. In the FL system, the UEs have no access to the amount of resources that other UEs contribute, but they can observe the pricing information of others to make decisions. Thus we adopt the Bertrand game to solve the incentive problem. While the UEs fight for market share through price competition, the MO can adjust its purchase according to the prices offered by the UEs, so as to achieve its performance with a minimum total investment. Next, we model the price competition between the UEs and their interaction with the MO as a Bertrand game. The game execution cycle is the time to complete an entire FL task with a continuous Igsuperscriptğ¼gI^{\text{g}}-round global iterations.

  1. 1.

    Strategic games can be divided into the following quantity-based games and price-based games [6].

    1. (a)

      Games based on commodity production, such as Cournot games and Stackelberg games, in which competing monopolists take the supply quantity of a commodity as a strategy to maximize their profits.

    2. (b)

      Games based on commodity price, such as Bertrand games, in which competing monopolists take the price of a commodity as a strategy to maximize their profits.

    In general, the monopolists cannot obtain each otherâ€™s production information, but they can easily observe the rivalsâ€™ product pricing from the market, which helps the monopolists to make decisions. The price of a commodity is a signal to coordinate the supply and demand of the commodity in the market.

  2. 2.

    In this paper, we motivate the UEs to participate in FL through pricing the consumed resources, and, therefore, the Bertrand game is adopted to solve problem (14).

    1. (a)

      In problem (14), multiple competitive UEs produce homogeneous products (computing and communication resources) and set the prices based on their specific production costs (determined by their respective energy consumption during FL) and othersâ€™ prices to meet the market demand (the FL performance ordered by the model server).

    2. (b)

      Similar to the monopolists in a oligopoly market, the UEs have no access to the amount of resources that others contribute to the FL task, but they can obtain the price-information of others to make decisions. Therefore, the proposed game belongs to the price-based games and we adopt the Bertrand game to analyze the incentive problem (14).

1) The objective of UEs: We represent the price asked by UE kğ‘˜k for training session tğ‘¡t by Ï±k,tsubscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\varrho_{k,t} (in Joule/iteration), which is the compensation required by UE kğ‘˜k for each local iteration over the dataset ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}. Denote the overall energy cost of UE kğ‘˜k for completing a round of local training and parameter transmission by Ïˆk,t=E~k,tF+E~k,tCsubscriptğœ“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript~ğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡Fsuperscriptsubscript~ğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡C\psi_{k,t}=\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{F}}+\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{C}}, and the payment of the MO to UE kğ‘˜k by Î¾k,t=Ï±k,tâ€‹Iksubscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜\xi_{k,t}=\varrho_{k,t}I_{k}. The aim of UE kğ‘˜k is to maximize its profit in the total Igsuperscriptğ¼gI^{\text{g}} rounds by choosing the optimal price profile Î“k=(Ï±k,1,â‹¯,Ï±k,Ig)subscriptÎ“ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜1â‹¯subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜superscriptğ¼g\Gamma_{k}=\left(\varrho_{k,1},\cdots,\varrho_{k,I^{\text{g}}}\right). This can be formulated as the following problem.

maxÎ“ksubscriptsubscriptÎ“ğ‘˜\displaystyle\max_{\Gamma_{k}}\; Uk=âˆ‘tâˆˆğ’¯(Î¾k,tâˆ’Ïˆk,t)=âˆ‘tâˆˆğ’¯(Ï±k,tâ€‹Ikâˆ’(E~k,tF+E~k,tC))subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¡ğ’¯subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ’¯subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript~ğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡Fsuperscriptsubscript~ğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡C\displaystyle U_{k}=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}(\xi_{k,t}-\psi_{k,t})=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}(\varrho_{k,t}I_{k}-(\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{F}}+\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{C}})) (13)
s.t. Ï±k,tâ‰¥0,âˆ€kâˆˆğ’¦,âˆ€tâˆˆğ’¯.formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡0formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘˜ğ’¦for-allğ‘¡ğ’¯\displaystyle\varrho_{k,t}\geq 0,\;\forall k\in{\mathcal{K}},\forall t\in{\mathcal{T}}. (13.1)

2) The objective of the MO: The MO aims to achieve its performance (including the global accuracy Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and the training parameters Igsuperscriptğ¼gI^{\text{g}}, Ttrnsuperscriptğ‘‡trnT^{\text{trn}} and Tcomsuperscriptğ‘‡comT^{\text{com}}) with a minimum total investment. minÎ˜subscriptÎ˜\displaystyle\min_{\Theta}\; US=âˆ‘tâˆˆğ’¯âˆ‘kâˆˆKÏ±k,tâ€‹Ik+12â€‹(âˆ‘kâˆˆK(Î¸k)2+2â€‹vâ€‹âˆ‘kâ‰ j(Î¸kâ€‹Î¸j)),subscriptğ‘ˆSsubscriptğ‘¡ğ’¯subscriptğ‘˜ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜12subscriptğ‘˜ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜22ğ‘£subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğœƒğ‘—\displaystyle U_{\text{S}}=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k\in K}\varrho_{k,t}I_{k}+\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\sum_{k\in K}(\theta_{k})^{2}+2v\sum_{k\neq j}(\theta_{k}\theta_{j})\Big{)}, (14)

  1. 1.

    The meaning of the first term âˆ‘tâˆˆğ’¯âˆ‘kâˆˆKÏ±k,tâ€‹Iksubscriptğ‘¡ğ’¯subscriptğ‘˜ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k\in K}\varrho_{k,t}I_{k}.

      Parameter Iksubscriptğ¼ğ‘˜I_{k} represents the required number of local iterations in each kthsuperscriptğ‘˜thk^{\text{th}} training session to achieve local accuracy Î¸ksubscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta_{k}.

    2. (b)

      Parameter Ï±k,tsubscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\varrho_{k,t} represents the price asked by UE kğ‘˜k for the tthsuperscriptğ‘¡tht^{\text{th}} training session.

    3. (c)

      Therefore, âˆ‘tâˆˆğ’¯âˆ‘kâˆˆKÏ±k,tâ€‹Iksubscriptğ‘¡ğ’¯subscriptğ‘˜ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k\in K}\varrho_{k,t}I_{k} represents the total payment of the server to all the UEs in the total Igsuperscriptğ¼gI^{\text{g}} rounds of local training.

  2. 2.

    The second term 12â€‹(âˆ‘kâˆˆK(Î¸k)2+2â€‹vâ€‹âˆ‘kâ‰ j(Î¸kâ€‹Î¸j))12subscriptğ‘˜ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜22ğ‘£subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğœƒğ‘—\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\sum_{k\in K}(\theta_{k})^{2}+2v\sum_{k\neq j}(\theta_{k}\theta_{j})\Big{)} considers the Resource Substitutability (RS) in a Bertrand game.

    1. (a)

      We note that the Bertrand game model is first proposed in [14]. The content related to the RS is in the second formula, Part 2, page 547 of ref. [14]. Next, we introduce it briefly.

    2. (b)

      According to ref. [15], the RS is an ability of a buyer to substitute one product (hold by some sellers) with other products (hold by other sellers) of similar functionality. The RS of a buyer is described by parameter vâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘£01v\in\left[0,1\right]. When v=0ğ‘£0v=0, there is no substitutability between products sold by different sellers, when v=1ğ‘£1v=1, the products sold by different sellers are completely homogeneous with each other. Please refer to it for more details.

    3. (c)

      In what follows, we explain how the RS is applied to our game framework for federated learning.

      The function of term 12â€‹(âˆ‘kâˆˆK(Î¸k)2+2â€‹vâ€‹âˆ‘kâ‰ j(Î¸kâ€‹Î¸j))12subscriptğ‘˜ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜22ğ‘£subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğœƒğ‘—\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\sum_{k\in K}(\theta_{k})^{2}+2v\sum_{k\neq j}(\theta_{k}\theta_{j})\Big{)} can be explained from the economic aspect, as it tasks the RS into account through parameter vğ‘£v.

      It is known that a major challenge to implement FL is to solve the non independent-and-identical distribution of the training data on different UEs. In the considered FL system, the model server faces a limited number of UEs to perform a FL task. If the server needs special datasets owned by certain UEs to train the learning model, the RS of different UEs is weak, namely vğ‘£v tends to 0; otherwise, the learning model of the server can be trained on any dataset owned by the UEs, namely, the datasts owned by different UEs have a strong RS, so vğ‘£v tends to 1.

    4. (d)

      The issue of statistical heterogeneity of training data is not discussed here as it is beyond the scope of this paper. In the simulation, we set v=0.5ğ‘£0.5v=0.5 as in [16] to represent a general case. In [16], the authors presented the similar RS-based utility function to address the spectrum allocation problem in multi-user cognitive radio networks. Readers can refer to the first formula in Sec. IV.A, page 4275 of [16] for detail.

IV Solution Of The Game

We first solve problems (13) and (14), respectively, and obtain the NE of the game. Then, an iterative algorithm is developed to find the NE in a distributed manner.

IV-1 Solve the MO problem (14)

In the Bertrand game, each UE kğ‘˜k first gives the resource price Î“ksubscriptÎ“ğ‘˜\Gamma_{k}. Then, the MO can find the optimal resource purchase Î˜Î˜\Theta according to Î“k,âˆ€kâˆˆğ’¦subscriptÎ“ğ‘˜for-allğ‘˜ğ’¦\Gamma_{k},\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}, by solving problem (14). U~S=âˆ‘tâˆˆğ’¯âˆ‘kâˆˆKÏ±k,tâ€‹Î·kâ€‹(1âˆ’Î¸k)+12â€‹(âˆ‘kâˆˆK(Î¸k)2+2â€‹vâ€‹âˆ‘kâ‰ j(Î¸kâ€‹Î¸j)).subscript~ğ‘ˆSsubscriptğ‘¡ğ’¯subscriptğ‘˜ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1subscriptğœƒğ‘˜12subscriptğ‘˜ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜22ğ‘£subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘—subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğœƒğ‘—\displaystyle\tilde{U}_{\text{S}}=\sum_{t\in\mathcal{T}}\sum_{k\in K}\varrho_{k,t}\eta_{k}\left(1-\theta_{k}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\sum_{k\in K}(\theta_{k})^{2}+2v\sum_{k\neq j}(\theta_{k}\theta_{j})\Big{)}. (16)

IV-2 Solve the UE problem (13)

IV-3 Find the NE of the game

At the NE of the game, neither the MO nor each of the UEs can get higher profit from changing the strategy profile, i.e., Î˜Î˜\Theta or Î“ksubscriptÎ“ğ‘˜\Gamma_{k}. Denote the NE strategy profile of the MO and the UEs by {Î˜^,Î“^1,â‹¯,Î“^k}^Î˜subscript^Î“1â‹¯subscript^Î“ğ‘˜\{\hat{\Theta},\hat{\Gamma}_{1},\cdots,\hat{\Gamma}_{k}\}, where Î˜^=(Î¸^1,â‹¯,Î¸^|ğ’¦|)^Î˜subscript^ğœƒ1â‹¯subscript^ğœƒğ’¦\hat{\Theta}=\left(\hat{\theta}_{1},\cdots,\hat{\theta}_{\left|\mathcal{K}\right|}\right) and Î“^k=(Ï±^k,1,â‹¯,Ï±^k,Ig)subscript^Î“ğ‘˜subscript^italic-Ï±ğ‘˜1â‹¯subscript^italic-Ï±ğ‘˜superscriptğ¼ğ‘”\hat{\Gamma}_{k}=\left(\hat{\varrho}_{k,1},\cdots,\hat{\varrho}_{k,I^{g}}\right). We propose an iterative algorithm to find the NE.

Let i=1,2,â‹¯ğ‘–12â‹¯i=1,2,\cdots denote the iteration numbers. In the ithsuperscriptğ‘–thi^{\text{th}} iteration, we use Î“kâ€‹[i]subscriptÎ“ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘–\Gamma_{k}[i], Î“âˆ’kâ€‹[i]subscriptÎ“ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘–\Gamma_{-k}[i] and Î˜â€‹[i]Î˜delimited-[]ğ‘–\Theta[i] to represent the pricing of UE kğ‘˜k, the pricing of the UEs in set ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} other than UE kğ‘˜k, and the resource purchase of the MO, respectively. Given that the pricing of all UEs are observable in a market, the following distributed algorithm is designed to find the NE.

Because Ukâ€‹(Ï±k,t)subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡U_{k}(\varrho_{k,t}) is strictly concave with respect to Ï±k,tsubscriptitalic-Ï±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\varrho_{k,t}, the upper bound on the iteration number of Algorithm 1 to reach the convergence threshold ÎÎ\Xi is ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡1Î)ğ’ª1Î\mathcal{O}(\log\frac{1}{\Xi}) [17] and the computational complexity of Algorithm 1 is logâ¡1Îâ€‹(K+Ig)1Îğ¾superscriptğ¼ğ‘”\log\frac{1}{\Xi}(K+I^{g}) [18]. Although it is assumed that all the UEs are willing to engage in the FL task, some of them cannot be selected because their computing power fails to meet the requirement of local relative accuracy Î¸ksubscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta_{k}. Then we apply constraint (14.1) to the outcome of Algorithm 1 and determine which UEs are qualified for the FL task. Finally, we give the execution process of the game in the following Algorithm 2, which is termed as the task-load-aware game-theoretic scheme (TLA-GTS)

In Algorithm 2, we initialize ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} as all the potential client UEs for the MO. After performing Algorithm 1, one can make the following choices according to the obtained solution. If the solution satisfies constraint (14.1), the algorithm terminates and the solution is taken as the NE of the game. Otherwise, the UE with the highest price is removed from set ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K}, and Algorithm 1 is performed again until constraint (14.1) is satisfied or set ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} is empty. An empty UE set indicates that the performance set by the MO (e.g., Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, Igsuperscriptğ¼gI^{\text{g}}, Ttrnsuperscriptğ‘‡trnT^{\text{trn}} and Tcomsuperscriptğ‘‡comT^{\text{com}}) cannot be achieved by the UEs. The MO needs to lower the performance metrics and restart the game. Algorithm 2 is implemented by performing Algorithm 1 for Kğ¾K times. Therefore, its computational complexity is logâ¡1Îâ€‹(K2+Kâ€‹Ig)1Îsuperscriptğ¾2ğ¾superscriptğ¼ğ‘”\log\frac{1}{\Xi}(K^{2}+KI^{g}).

The other simulation parameters include dataset size |ğ’Ÿk|=8Ã—107subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜8superscript107|\mathcal{D}_{k}|=8\times 10^{7} [11], the number of CPU cycles for computing one data sample ck=15subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜15c_{k}=15[11], the size of model parameters L=0.1ğ¿0.1L=0.1 Mb, the global iteration number Ig=10superscriptğ¼g10I^{\text{g}}=10, the duration for each local training Ttrn=2superscriptğ‘‡trn2T^{\text{trn}}=2s, the duration for each parameter transmission Tcom=0.2superscriptğ‘‡com0.2T^{\text{com}}=0.2s, the CPU parameter Î½k=10âˆ’28subscriptğœˆğ‘˜superscript1028\nu_{k}=10^{-28}[11], the bandwidth allocated to each UE W=1ğ‘Š1W=1 MHz, the noise power Ïƒ2=10âˆ’9superscriptğœ2superscript109\sigma^{2}=10^{-9}, the BER requirement 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3}, the substitutability factor for the MO v=0.5ğ‘£0.5v=0.5, Î·k=1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1\eta_{k}=1 in eq. (2), and Î¶=1ğœ1\zeta=1 in eq. (3).

First, we show the impact of different EX-task load fk,texsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} on the pricing of the UEs. For that purpose, we set fk,t=0ex=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡0ex0f_{k,t=0}^{\text{ex}}=0 for all the 4 UEs. Following eq. (6), fk,texsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} of the UEs in 3 consecutive training sessions (e.g., t=1,2,3ğ‘¡123t=1,2,3) are estimated as f1,tex={0,0.5,1.5}superscriptsubscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¡ex00.51.5f_{1,t}^{\text{ex}}=\{0,0.5,1.5\}, f2,tex={0.5,1,1}superscriptsubscriptğ‘“2ğ‘¡ex0.511f_{2,t}^{\text{ex}}=\{0.5,1,1\}, f3,tex={1,1.5,1}superscriptsubscriptğ‘“3ğ‘¡ex11.51f_{3,t}^{\text{ex}}=\{1,1.5,1\}, and f4,tex={1,0,1}superscriptsubscriptğ‘“4ğ‘¡ex101f_{4,t}^{\text{ex}}=\{1,0,1\}, respectively. Fig. 2 shows the convergence of the prices of the UEs in the 3 training sessions.

As shown in Fig. 2, the UEs with lower fk,texsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} have a price advantage over the UEs with higher fk,texsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} in each training session. As the energy cost for data uploading Ek,tCsuperscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡CE_{k,t}^{\text{C}} is negligible compared to that for model training Ek,tFsuperscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡FE_{k,t}^{\text{F}}, the results imply that the pricing of a UE is sensitive to its available computing power. To incentive the UEs with higher fk,texsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¡exf_{k,t}^{\text{ex}} (i.e. lower-level of available computing power) to engage in an FL task, the MO has to pay a higher price for the resource usage.

Next, we show the performance of the proposed TLA-GTS, i.e., Algorithm 2 on a real FL task. The task is to classify handwritten digits using the MNIST dataset [20]. The distribution of the dataset over the UEs are balanced but non-i.i.d, and the training model is a 2-layer deep neural networks (DNN), consisting of one flatten layer, two fully-connected layers with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation and a log-softmax output layer. For each ordered model accuracy {.65, .7, .75, .8}, 100 experiments (game cycles) were performed. Fig. 3 shows the empirical cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the 100 experiments. One can see that the TLA-GTS can effectively motivate the autonomous UEs to help the MO achieve the accuracy goal of the FL task.

Finally, we verify the superiority of TLA-GTS by comparing with other two schemes. Given that most of the related works do not consider the userâ€™s EX-task load, the first scheme to be compared is the game-theoretic scheme without the task-load-aware mechanism. It is termed as the pure-GTS, which still uses the proposed game framework, but the energy cost of a UE does not consider the impact of its EX-task load, i.e., E~k,tF=Î½kâ€‹(fk)2â€‹Ttrnsuperscriptsubscript~ğ¸ğ‘˜ğ‘¡Fsubscriptğœˆğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘‡trn\tilde{E}_{k,t}^{\text{F}}=\nu_{k}\left(f_{k}\right)^{2}T^{\text{trn}} in eq. (7). Another scheme to be compared is the independent linear pricing strategy (ILPS), in which, each UE prices the MO independently using a linear pricing strategy based on its available resources, regardless of the pricing of other UEs. For each ordered model accuracy, the profits of the UEs using the different schemes are shown in Fig. 4. From Fig. 4, one can see that both the game-theoretic schemes TLA-GTS and pure-GTS outperform the ILPS as they bring higher profits for each of the UEs. This is because the game-theoretic schemes can price the resources of UEs based on their energy cost and the pricing of other UEs in the same training session. Furthermore, one can also note that the TLA-GTS outperforms the pure-GTS in all cases. This is because that the energy cost of a UE in an FL task depends not only on the FL-task load but also on the EX-task load, which causes the UEs to produce the same amount of CPU cycles but consume different amount of energy. Hence, the TLA-GTS brings the UEs the highest profits in the game.

VI Conclusion

This paper has proposed a game theoretic approach to motivate UEs to participate in FL and the NE of the game has been obtained by a distributed iterative algorithm. Simulation results have verified the effectiveness of the proposed approaches.
